did.unittitle: Papers of John Randolph of Roanoke 1781-1860, [n.d.]
did.physdesc: This collection consists of ca. 815 items, chiefly correspondence by and to John Randolph of Roanoke.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers of John Randolph of Roanoke, Accession#, Special Collections, University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was acquired through gift, purchase and loan, ca. 1930-present.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: John Randolph was born on June 2, 1773, at Cawsons, a plantation in Prince George County, Virginia. He was educated at the College of New Jersey, Columbia College, and the College of William and Mary. He studied law with his relative Edmund Randolph, then attorney general of the United States.

Randolph was elected to the House of Representatives in 1799 and served in Congress almost continually until his death in 1833. He was a brilliant orator and was known and feared for his biting and sarcastic wit. An outspoken champion of individual liberty, he staunchly defended the Constitution and states' rights, and his views were influential in the South long after his death.

By 1801 Randolph was chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee. He was one of the managers appointed by the House of Representatives in January 1804 to conduct the impeachment proceedings against Judge John Pickering, and in December of the same year against Supreme Court Justice Samuel.

On principle Randolph opposed President Thomas Jefferson's attempt to obtain West Florida from Spain. He voted against the Embargo Act of 1807 and opposed the War of 1812. This cost him reelection, but he was back in the House two years later, in 1815. An ardent states' rights advocate, Randolph denounced the tariff of 1816, which he believed harmed Southern interests, and opposed chartering the Second Bank of the United States. In 1820 he denounced the Missouri Compromise as a cowardly surrender to antislavery agitators. His impassioned denunciations of Henry Clay and John Quincy Adams led to a duel (1826) with Clay.

Randolph was appointed to the United States Senate on December 8, 1825, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of James Barbour; he served from December 26, 1825, to March 3, 1827 and was unsuccessful in his bid for reelection in 1827. He was elected to the House and served from 1827 to 1829.

He was a member of the Virginia constitutional convention at Richmond in 1829. President Andrew appointed Randolph United States Minister to Russia in 1830. His health deteriorated soon after his arrival in St. Petersburg, so he returned home in 1831. Following his return he denounced Jackson's proclamation against nullification. Randolph was elected to the Twenty-third Congress and served from March 4, 1833, until his death in Philadelphia, Pa., May 24, 1833. He was buried at his residence, 'Roanoke,' in Charlotte County, Virginia and later re-interred at 'Hollywood,' Richmond, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of ca. 815 items, chiefly correspondence by and to John Randolph of Roanoke.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in two series. Series I: Letters and Documents, is arranged chronologically. Series II: Prints.

did.unittitle: John Randolph to Richard E. Meade, 1803 December 27
did.physdesc: ALS, 3 pp., including attached address leaf, text on p. 3 partially obscured by two small holes. #15289.

scopecontent.p: Randolph writes to the Amelia County physician regarding the latter's dejection and explaining "I am too well apprized, my dear friend, that our passions govern us, to make a senseless parade of governing them. I have proved the truth of this opinion too often, & too fatally, not to rank those who advocate the opposite doctrine in the class of knaves or fools, or of that very good sort of people, who, rather than not have something to say by way of consoling a friend in distress, condescend to advance opinions which they themselves disbelieve."

did.physdesc: ALS, 1 pp. on 2 leaves including attached address leaf. #15289.

scopecontent.p: Randolph reports that [Joseph] Bryan has reached Savannah safely and that he himself has retired to Bizarre as he is "unfit for the world & it's society" though he would have liked to have stopped in Amelia to see Meade. He concludes with a note that Miss Vixen and her foal are doing well and a request to forward two vest patterns.

did.unittitle: John Randolph to [Anne Cary Randolph Morris], 1814 October 31
did.physdesc: ALS, 14 pp. on 13 l.; 19th century copy in unidentified hand. #10652.

scopecontent.p: In a widely circulated and copied letter concerning the scandal at Bizarre, Randolph writes to Anne Cary Randolph Morris accusing her of the deaths of her child and her lover, Richard Randolph, John Randolph's brother. Anne Cary Randolph Morris refuted the charges in an 1815 January 16 letter (q.v.) to Randolph.

did.unittitle: John Randolph to Richard Stanford, 1814 December 2
did.physdesc: ALS, 2 pp. on 1 l.; with attached address leaf; postmarked Philadelphia PA, December 2. #3339.

scopecontent.p: Notes on address leaf in Randolph's? hand refer to the scandal at Bizarre, Richard Randolph, Theodorick Randolph, and Anne Cary Randolph Morris. "Nothing but my utter incredulity that my poor brother could perpetrate so foul a deed as incest, seduction & murder could have blinded me to the Truth. The Story he told me about poor The, our brother, I knew to be false, but whilst his word was his oath in all matters that might advantage him or disadvantage his enemy he over simpled a white lie to serve friend or foe[.] The singular benevolence of his character deceived himself & every body else. I who had as lief taken Tartaric forced my tastes[?] and pretended to like Randolph Harrison's wretched"

scopecontent.p: Informs Randolph that he has no information about Mr. Gilmer but expects Mr. Walsh in a few days. He also tells him not be uneasy about the pamphlet because it finally came to Mr. Walsh through Mr. Hopkinson and is now in Baltimore ready to be published if not already published in Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: John Randolph to Henry Carrington 1818 August 13
did.physdesc: ALS, 2 p. on 1 l. #5718-e

scopecontent.p: Says that he could write a letter of advice along the lines of a popular pamphlet of some time ago, entitled Letter from an old politician to a young prince but it would be unnecessary since he already has Edmund Burke. Instead he will send a paper on The motives of France in aiding us in our contest for Independency against the mother country. Randolph also asks two favors of his young friend, that he take back the mule and agree to dine with him and a relative of Colonel Taylor of Caroline.

did.unittitle: Maria Edgeworth to John Randolph 1822 June 13
did.physdesc: ALS, 4 p. on 1 l. with attached address leaf. #5718-e

scopecontent.p: Reminds Randolph of his promise to send her an American poem which was in the style of Lord Byron, and arranges to give him a copy of the memoirs of her father, Richard Edgeworth, which she had recently completed. She also asks him to visit her at Edgeworth's Town, if he should ever visit Ireland. Note on address leaf says "I seal with the rose, thistle & shamrock--What is the American emblem? Or is there one?"

did.unittitle: Timothy Pickering to John Randolph 1828 April 12
did.physdesc: ALS, 1 p. on 1 l.

scopecontent.p: Notifies Randolph that he has sent a dozen copies of the first edition of his Review to a Baltimore bookseller, who would forward them on to Randolph in Washington. He also asks Randolph to do his best to defeat the Tariff of 1828 (the Tariff of Abominations) with its recent amendments, "kill the ravenous monster, whose voracity increases with what it feeds upon. It belongs not to a legislature to prescribe how individuals shall employ their heads, their hands, or their property, in the prosecution of their own chosen lawful occupations."

did.unittitle: "John Randolph Esq.", [ante 1833]

scopecontent.p: "I have been the steady, firm, constant, and strenuous advocate, to the best of my poor ability, of the oppressed people of Ireland--In the course of a not uneventful life, I have seen many things, I have seen a black swan,-- but I never have yet seen that rara avis in terries, an Irish Tory, or the man who had seen one."
